column2: amberar68, 3-6 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: My 4 year old daughter was given chloral hydrate as a sedative before a voiding cystourethrogram. When it first started to take effect we thought it was kinda funny.  She was loopy and a little drunk acting. We figured she would be that way for a few minutes then slip into a real sleepy state. WRONG!  Within probably 10 minutes, she went from silly, to so dizzy she couldn't walk, her head was practically spinning around uncontrollably, arms and legs flailing around.  She became very agitated, angry and combatative. This normally very loving child started screaming, crying and talking very mean and ugly to everyone. She told a nurse she was going to beat her up and tear her into little pieces. She bit me (her mother)numerous times, she pinched a nurse so hard it left a mark. Needless to say, this all scared me to death. They ended up giving her a big dose of benadryl to knock her out while the chloral hydrate wore off. She finally went completely out and they put us in a room in the ER so she could sleep it off. Then finally we were able to do the procedure, because she had to be awake enough to go pee pee.  That was terrible in itself because she was too awake and didnt have the right amount of sedation to make it comfortable for her.  Overall the experience was horrible and absolutely no one will be giving any of my children chloral hydrate ever again.

column9: I was put on this because I couldn't sleep due to remembering my past. I have PTSD. I am re-experiencing and remembering everything NOW w/ feeling all the abuse by two monstors. They were not parents. This drug has helped me sleep most of the time, unfortunately I also have to take it to calm down after a very hard setion w/ my therapist or reliving something in my own home. Anyone who has PTSD is in for a horrible rollercoaster ride and needs support. It is essential. Outside support by a compassionate,understanding and qualified/experienced therapist or psychologist is a MUST. Do not go it alone. Use great books, like Courage to Heal by Ellen Bass. Know others are out here and will hold your hand-I am.
